description: From Middle English minde, m√ºnde, »ùem√ºnde, from Old English mynd, ƒ°emynd (‚Äúmemory‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *mundi, *gamundi, from Proto-Germanic *mundiz, *gamundiz (‚Äúmemory, remembrance‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *m√©ntis (‚Äúthought‚Äù) (compare also mantis, via Greek), from the root *men- (‚Äúto think‚Äù). Cognate with Old High German gimunt (‚Äúmind, memory‚Äù), Danish minde (‚Äúmemory‚Äù), Swedish minne (‚Äúmemory‚Äù), Icelandic minni (‚Äúmemory, recall, recollection‚Äù), Gothic êåºêåøêåΩêå≥êçÉ (munds, ‚Äúmemory, mind‚Äù), Latin mƒìns (‚Äúmind, reason‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç (m√°nas), Ancient Greek ŒºŒ≠ŒΩŒøœÇ (m√©nos), Albanian m√´nd (‚Äúmind, reason‚Äù). Doublet of mantra. Related to Old English myntan (‚Äúto mean, intend, purpose, determine, resolve‚Äù). More at mint.

entries.meaning: The capability for rational thought.
examples: Despite advancing age, his mind was still as sharp as ever.

entries.meaning: The ability to be aware of things.
examples: There was no doubt in his mind that they would win.

entries.meaning: The ability to remember things.
examples: My mind just went blank.

entries.meaning: The ability to focus the thoughts.
examples: I can‚Äôt keep my mind on what I‚Äôm doing.

entries.meaning: Somebody that embodies certain mental qualities.
examples: He was one of history‚Äôs greatest minds.

entries.meaning: Judgment, opinion, or view.
examples: He changed his mind after hearing the speech.

entries.meaning: Desire, inclination, or intention.
examples: She had a mind to go to Paris.
I have half a mind to do it myself.
I am of a mind to listen.

entries.meaning: A healthy mental state.
examples: I, ______ being of sound mind and body, do hereby¬†[‚Ä¶]
You are losing your mind.

entries.meaning: (philosophy) The non-material substance or set of processes in which consciousness, perception, affectivity, judgement, thinking, and will are based.
examples: The mind is a process of the brain.

entries.meaning: Continual prayer on a dead person's behalf for a period after their death.
examples: a month's [or monthly] mind; a year's mind

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Attention, consideration or thought.
examples: They are the ‚Äútars‚Äù who give mind to the spreading sail, and their bold courage is the pabulum which will preserve our sea-girt isle in its vernal green to furthest posterity.

verbs.description: mind (third-person singular simple present minds, present participle minding, simple past and past participle minded)

entries.meaning: To bring or recall to mind; to remember; bear or keep in mind.
examples: Mind to-morrow's early meeting!

entries.meaning: (now regional) To remember. [from 14th c.]
examples: The land where I shall mind you not / Is the land where all's forgot.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or dialectal) To remind; put one's mind on.
examples: I desire to mind those persons of what Saint Austin hath said.

entries.meaning: To turn one's mind to; to observe; to notice.
To regard with attention; to treat as of consequence.
examples: It's the worst thing that can ever happen to you in all your life, and you've got to mind it‚Äîyou've got to mind it. They'll come saying, 'Bear up‚Äîtrust to time.' No, no; they're wrong. Mind it.

entries.meaning: (chiefly imperative) To pay attention or heed to so as to obey; hence to obey; to make sure, to take care (that). [from 17th c.]
examples: Mind you don't knock that glass over.

entries.meaning: (now rare except in phrases) To pay attention to, in the sense of occupying one's mind with, to heed. [from 15th c.]
examples: You should mind your own business.

entries.meaning: To look after, to take care of, especially for a short period of time. [from 17th c.]
examples: Would you mind my bag for me?

entries.meaning: To be careful about. [from 18th c.]
(now obsolete outside dialect) To purpose, intend, plan.
(UK, Ireland) Take note; used to point out an exception or caveat.
examples: I'm not very healthy. I do eat fruit sometimes, mind.

entries.meaning: (originally and chiefly in negative or interrogative constructions) To dislike, to object to; to be bothered by. [from 16th c.]
examples: I wouldn't mind an ice cream right now.
Do you mind if I smoke?
